title: Isaiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 31 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 31.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:1, what do those who go down to Egypt for help trust in?
options: Chariots and horsemen
Gold and silver idols
The Holy One of Israel
The LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Chariots and horsemen
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 states they trust in chariots and horsemen because they are many and strong.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 31:2 say the LORD will do against the house of evildoers?
options: Bring evil
Bless them
Ignore them
Help them
questions.correctAnswer: Bring evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:2 states that the LORD will bring evil against the house of evildoers.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 31:3 describes the Egyptians as God and their horses as spirit.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:3 says the Egyptians are men and not God, and their horses are flesh, not spirit.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:4, the LORD is compared to which animal roaring on its prey?
options: Lion
Eagle
Wolf
Bear
questions.correctAnswer: Lion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:4 compares the LORD to a lion and young lion roaring on its prey.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:5, how will the LORD of hosts defend Jerusalem?
options: As birds flying
Like a mighty warrior
With a strong shield
By sending angels
questions.correctAnswer: As birds flying
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:5 says the LORD will defend Jerusalem as birds flying.

questions.question: Who are the people told to turn to in Isaiah 31:6?
options: The LORD
Egyptians
Assyrians
Their idols
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:6 instructs to turn unto the LORD from whom Israel has revolted.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 31:7 says that every man will keep his idols of silver and gold.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:7 says every man shall cast away his idols of silver and gold.

questions.question: What will happen to the Assyrian according to Isaiah 31:8?
options: Fall by the sword
Become king
Build a city
Make peace
questions.correctAnswer: Fall by the sword
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:8 says the Assyrian will fall with the sword, not of a mighty man.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:9, what are the princes afraid of?
options: The ensign
Their own soldiers
The horses
The idols
questions.correctAnswer: The ensign
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:9 states the princes shall be afraid of the ensign.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 31:1: 'Woe to them that go down to ______ for help;'
options: Egypt
Babylon
Assyria
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 begins with woe to those who go down to Egypt for help.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 31:3 say will happen when the LORD stretches out his hand?
options: Both he that helpeth and he that is helped shall fall
The Egyptians will prosper
Horses will multiply
The LORD will hide
questions.correctAnswer: Both he that helpeth and he that is helped shall fall
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:3 says when the LORD stretches out his hand, both helpers and those helped shall fall.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 31:4, the LORD will abase himself for the noise of the shepherds.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:4 says the LORD will not abase himself for the noise of the shepherds.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:5, what will the LORD do besides defend Jerusalem?
options: Deliver and preserve it
Destroy it
Ignore it
Punish it
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver and preserve it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:5 says the LORD will defend, deliver, and preserve Jerusalem.

questions.question: What have the children of Israel deeply done, according to Isaiah 31:6?
options: Revolted from the LORD
Prayed continually
Built altars
Trusted in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Revolted from the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:6 calls to turn unto Him from whom Israel has deeply revolted.

questions.question: What do the idols made by their own hands represent in Isaiah 31:7?
options: A sin
A blessing
A sign of victory
A treasure
questions.correctAnswer: A sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:7 says the idols made are unto them for a sin.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 31 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is tempted to rely on worldly power and resources instead of God. Based on Isaiah 31:1, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust in the Holy One of Israel rather than many horses and chariots
Seek help only from strong horsemen
Depend on the number of chariots for security
Look to Egypt for ultimate protection
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the Holy One of Israel rather than many horses and chariots
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 warns against relying on Egypt and their horses and chariots, emphasizing that true help comes from trusting the Holy One of Israel. This teaches us to place our faith in God rather than worldly strength or numbers. See also verses 3 and 6 for God’s superiority over flesh and the call to turn to Him.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:4 illustrate God's attitude towards those who oppose His people, and what does this teach about His protection?
options: God is like a roaring lion who is not afraid of many shepherds, showing He will fight for Zion
God hides from the noise of enemies and waits for help
God is silent and passive when His people are attacked
God encourages His people to fight their own battles
questions.correctAnswer: God is like a roaring lion who is not afraid of many shepherds, showing He will fight for Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 4 uses the metaphor of a lion unafraid of many shepherds to demonstrate God's strength and courage in defending His people. This assures believers of God's active protection and encourages trust in His power rather than fear of enemies. See also verses 5 and 9 for God's defense of Jerusalem and Zion.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with idolatry and guilt. Based on Isaiah 31:7, what biblical insight would encourage them toward repentance?
options: Cast away idols of silver and gold made by your own hands for sin
Keep the idols as a reminder of past mistakes
Idols made by others are acceptable
Idolatry is not a serious sin
questions.correctAnswer: Cast away idols of silver and gold made by your own hands for sin
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:7 calls for rejecting idols crafted by human hands as they are sins. This teaches the importance of repentance and turning away from anything that replaces God in our lives. It encourages believers to forsake idolatry as a step toward spiritual restoration. See also verse 6 about turning back to God.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:3 describe the difference between trusting in Egypt and trusting in the LORD, and what practical application does this have for daily faith?
options: Egyptians are men and horses are flesh, but God is Spirit; trust God not flesh
Egyptians have more power than God
Trust in many horses is better than trusting in God
God cannot help when men fail
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptians are men and horses are flesh, but God is Spirit; trust God not flesh
questions.explanation: Verse 3 emphasizes that Egypt and its horses are mortal and limited, unlike the LORD who is Spirit and sovereign. This teaches believers to rely on God's spiritual power rather than human strength or resources in daily life. See verses 1 and 6 for further calls to trust and turn to God.

questions.question: What encouragement does Isaiah 31:5 give about God's care for Jerusalem, and how can this be applied to a believer's trust in God's protection?
options: God defends, delivers, and preserves Jerusalem like birds flying
Jerusalem must defend itself without God's help
God ignores Jerusalem's troubles
Jerusalem's fate is in the hands of its enemies
questions.correctAnswer: God defends, delivers, and preserves Jerusalem like birds flying
questions.explanation: Verse 5 uses the imagery of birds flying to illustrate God's swift and comprehensive protection over Jerusalem. This encourages believers to trust God's vigilant care and deliverance in times of trouble. See also verses 4 and 9 which highlight God's fighting for Zion and His fire in Jerusalem.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by enemies and opposition. Based on Isaiah 31:8, what truth about God's justice and deliverance would you share?
options: The Assyrian will fall by the sword, fleeing and discomfited, showing God's judgment
Enemies will always triumph over God’s people
God will not intervene in battles
The sword of a mighty man will always prevail
questions.correctAnswer: The Assyrian will fall by the sword, fleeing and discomfited, showing God's judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 8 promises that the Assyrian enemy will be defeated by God's judgment, fleeing in fear. This reassures believers that God is just and will deliver His people from oppression. See also verses 4 and 9 for God's power over enemies.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:2 teach us about God's wisdom and His commitment to justice in dealing with evildoers?
options: God is wise and will bring evil upon evildoers without retracting His words
God is uncertain and may change His mind about justice
God ignores the actions of evildoers
God protects evildoers from consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God is wise and will bring evil upon evildoers without retracting His words
questions.explanation: Verse 2 highlights God's wisdom and firm resolve to bring judgment on evildoers, showing His commitment to justice. This teaches believers about God's righteous discipline and encourages trust in His sovereign plans. See also verses 8 and 9 for God's action against enemies.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:6, what is the proper response for those who have deeply revolted against God?
options: Turn unto the LORD
Continue in rebellion
Trust in human strength
Seek help from idols
questions.correctAnswer: Turn unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 6 calls for repentance and turning back to God for those who have rebelled. This teaches the importance of humility and renewed faith as the basis for restoration. See also verses 1 and 7 for the consequences of not turning to God.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 31:9 teaches that the princes will be confident and unafraid because of the LORD's fire in Zion and furnace in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:9 states that the princes shall be afraid of the ensign because of the LORD's fire in Zion and furnace in Jerusalem, indicating fear and trembling rather than confidence. This shows God's fearsome power against enemies.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 31:1, trusting in many horses and chariots is a wise and godly strategy for protection.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 warns against trusting in many horses and chariots as a source of help, emphasizing instead the need to look to the Holy One of Israel. This teaches that reliance on worldly power is misguided.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 31:4 compares the LORD to a _____ and young lion roaring on his prey, unafraid of many shepherds.
options: lion
eagle
bear
serpent
questions.correctAnswer: lion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:4 uses the image of a lion and young lion roaring on its prey to describe God's fearless defense of Zion, illustrating His strength and courage.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 31:3, what happens to those who help and those who are helped by Egypt when the LORD stretches out His hand?
options: Both the helper and the helped shall fall and fail
Only the helper will be saved
Only the helped will stand strong
They will both be victorious
questions.correctAnswer: Both the helper and the helped shall fall and fail
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that when the LORD stretches out His hand, both those who help Egypt and those helped will fall together, showing the futility of relying on Egypt instead of God. This encourages dependence on God alone.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:5 describe the manner in which the LORD will protect Jerusalem, and what practical lesson does this teach about God's care?
options: Like birds flying, the LORD will defend, deliver, and preserve Jerusalem
Like a fortress, Jerusalem must defend itself
Like a silent guardian, God watches but does not act
Like a distant king, God remains uninvolved
questions.correctAnswer: Like birds flying, the LORD will defend, deliver, and preserve Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Verse 5 uses the metaphor of birds flying to show God's swift and protective care over Jerusalem, teaching believers to trust God's active defense and preservation in their lives.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the strength of opposing forces. How does Isaiah 31:8 encourage perseverance and faith in God’s deliverance?
options: The enemy will fall and flee from the sword, showing God’s power to save
Opposition will always overpower the believer
God will not intervene in conflicts
Survival depends solely on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: The enemy will fall and flee from the sword, showing God’s power to save
questions.explanation: Verse 8 assures that the Assyrian enemy will be defeated and discomfited, encouraging believers to persevere and trust God's deliverance despite overwhelming opposition. See also verses 2 and 9.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 31:2 teach about God's nature in dealing with the words He has spoken about judgment?
options: God will not call back His words and will bring judgment on evildoers
God sometimes regrets His judgments
God is unsure about punishing evildoers
God ignores evil and lets it continue
questions.correctAnswer: God will not call back His words and will bring judgment on evildoers
questions.explanation: Verse 2 explains that God, being wise, will bring the pronouncement of judgment to pass without retracting His words, showing His faithfulness and righteousness. This calls believers to respect God's justice.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 31.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:1, why is it considered a mistake to rely on Egypt for help?
options: Because they do not seek the LORD
Because Egypt is too far away
Because Egypt has no horses
Because Egypt is weak in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because they do not seek the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 warns that those who trust in Egypt and their horses and chariots do not look unto the Holy One of Israel nor seek the LORD.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 31:2 suggest about God's wisdom and the certainty of His actions?
options: God is wise and will bring evil without recalling His words
God is uncertain and often changes His mind
God only brings good and mercy
God is silent in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God is wise and will bring evil without recalling His words
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:2 emphasizes God's wisdom and that He will bring about judgment which He will not retract.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:3, what is the significance of contrasting Egyptians and their horses as 'men' and 'flesh' rather than God and spirit?
options: To highlight the limited power of Egypt compared to God's sovereignty
To emphasize the physical strength of Egypt
To show that Egypt is divine
To suggest Egyptians are immortal
questions.correctAnswer: To highlight the limited power of Egypt compared to God's sovereignty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:3 contrasts the mortality and limited nature of Egypt and its horses with the spirit and power of God, underscoring reliance on God instead of flesh.

questions.question: Isaiah 31:4 uses the imagery of a lion and young lion roaring on its prey. What literary device is primarily at work here?
options: Simile
Metaphor
Alliteration
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses 'like as the lion and the young lion roaring' to compare God's fearless defense to a lion's roar, a classic example of simile.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:4, what does the LORD of hosts promise to do for Mount Zion?
options: Come down to fight for it
Leave it to the shepherds
Hide it in the wilderness
Destroy it
questions.correctAnswer: Come down to fight for it
questions.explanation: The LORD of hosts will actively defend Mount Zion by coming down to fight for it, as stated in Isaiah 31:4.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:5 describe God's protection over Jerusalem?
options: As birds flying, defending and delivering it
As a fortress built by men
As an army of chariots
As a river surrounding it
questions.correctAnswer: As birds flying, defending and delivering it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:5 uses the imagery of birds flying to depict God’s swift and protective defense of Jerusalem.

questions.question: What is the call to action in Isaiah 31:6 directed at the people of Israel?
options: To turn unto the LORD from whom they have deeply revolted
To flee to Egypt for safety
To build more idols
To join the Assyrians
questions.correctAnswer: To turn unto the LORD from whom they have deeply revolted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:6 urges Israel to repent and return to God after their deep revolt.

questions.question: Isaiah 31:7 mentions idols of silver and gold. What does it say will happen to these idols?
options: Every man will cast them away for sin
They will be blessed by the LORD
They will grow in power
They will be hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Every man will cast them away for sin
questions.explanation: The verse states that idols, made by human hands, will be discarded as they are considered sin.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:8, how will the Assyrian fall?
options: By the sword, not of a mighty man
By famine and plague
By betrayal within
By natural disaster
questions.correctAnswer: By the sword, not of a mighty man
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:8 says the Assyrian will fall by the sword, but not one wielded by a mighty or mean man, indicating a divine or unusual cause.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:9, what causes fear among the Assyrian princes?
options: The ensign of the LORD whose fire is in Zion
The strength of the Egyptian army
The arrival of the shepherds
The rising floodwaters
questions.correctAnswer: The ensign of the LORD whose fire is in Zion
questions.explanation: The princes fear the LORD’s banner, symbolizing His fiery judgment and presence in Zion per Isaiah 31:9.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 31 portrays Egypt as a divine protector for Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:3 explicitly states that Egyptians are men and not God, emphasizing their limited power compared to the LORD.

questions.question: Which New Testament imagery parallels the LORD defending Jerusalem 'as birds flying' in Isaiah 31:5?
options: Jesus comparing Himself to a hen gathering her chicks (Luke 13:34)
Paul’s description of the armor of God (Ephesians 6)
The vision of the four horsemen (Revelation 6)
The parable of the mustard seed (Matthew 13)
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus comparing Himself to a hen gathering her chicks (Luke 13:34)
questions.explanation: The protective imagery of birds in Isaiah 31:5 is echoed by Jesus in Luke 13:34, where He laments over Jerusalem like a hen gathering her chicks.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:1-3 reflect the historical context of Israel’s alliances in the ancient Near East?
options: It critiques reliance on Egypt’s military power instead of trusting God
It commands Israel to ally with Egypt
It supports forming coalitions with Assyria
It encourages Israel to isolate itself from neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: It critiques reliance on Egypt’s military power instead of trusting God
questions.explanation: The chapter reflects Israel’s political situation, warning against dependence on Egyptian horses and chariots rather than the LORD (Isaiah 31:1-3).

questions.question: The phrase 'the LORD of hosts' in Isaiah 31:4 and 31:5 is a title emphasizing what aspect of God?
options: His sovereign command over heavenly armies
His mercy toward sinners
His role as a healer
His creation of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: His sovereign command over heavenly armies
questions.explanation: 'LORD of hosts' refers to God’s supreme authority over the angelic armies, highlighting His power to defend Zion (Isaiah 31:4-5).

questions.question: What typological significance might the 'lion and young lion' in Isaiah 31:4 have in a broader biblical context?
options: Representing the Messiah’s strength and courage
Symbolizing the defeat of Israel
Depicting Egypt’s power
Referring to a literal lion hunt
questions.correctAnswer: Representing the Messiah’s strength and courage
questions.explanation: The lion motif in Isaiah 31:4 can be seen as a type foreshadowing the Messiah’s fearless and powerful defense of His people, a theme developed in Revelation and Psalms.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 31 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 31 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:1, what is the primary reason for God's woe against those who seek help from Egypt?
options: They trust in many horses and chariots instead of the Holy One of Israel
They worship the Egyptian gods alongside Israel's God
They refuse to fight their own battles
They build idols of gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: They trust in many horses and chariots instead of the Holy One of Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1 condemns those who rely on Egypt's military power—horses and chariots—rather than trusting in God, the Holy One of Israel. This reflects a failure to seek divine help as taught throughout Scripture (e.g., Psalm 20:7; Jeremiah 17:5; Proverbs 3:5; 2 Chronicles 20:15).

questions.question: What characteristic of God is highlighted in Isaiah 31:2 concerning His response to evildoers?
options: He is wise and will bring evil without recalling His words
He is slow to anger and full of mercy
He immediately forgives those who repent
He ignores the actions of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: He is wise and will bring evil without recalling His words
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:2 emphasizes God's wisdom and His sure judgment against evildoers, highlighting His faithfulness and justice. Similar themes are found in Romans 1:18; Nahum 1:2; Psalm 7:11; and Hebrews 10:31, underscoring God's righteous wrath.

questions.question: In Isaiah 31:3, what distinction is made between the Egyptians and the LORD?
options: Egyptians are men and horses are flesh, but the LORD is spirit
Egyptians worship idols, but the LORD is silent
Egyptians are strong, but the LORD is weak
Egyptians have magic, but the LORD has miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Egyptians are men and horses are flesh, but the LORD is spirit
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:3 contrasts the mortal, physical nature of Egypt's help with the spiritual, sovereign nature of God. This distinction recalls John 4:24; Romans 8:9; 2 Corinthians 3:17; and Psalm 104:4, affirming God's transcendent, spiritual being.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:4 describe the LORD's attitude towards opposition against Mount Zion?
options: He will not fear nor be intimidated by the noise of many shepherds
He will hide and wait until the enemy leaves
He will negotiate peace with the shepherds
He will flee from the multitude
questions.correctAnswer: He will not fear nor be intimidated by the noise of many shepherds
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:4 portrays God as a lion who is fearless against overwhelming opposition, showing His power and courage in defending His people. This imagery aligns with Revelation 5:5; Hosea 11:10; Psalm 18:33; and 1 Peter 5:8, illustrating God's sovereign protection.

questions.question: What metaphor does Isaiah 31:5 use to describe the LORD’s defense of Jerusalem?
options: As birds flying to defend and preserve the city
As a mighty fortress surrounded by walls
As a consuming fire burning the enemies
As a shepherd guarding his sheep
questions.correctAnswer: As birds flying to defend and preserve the city
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:5 uses the imagery of birds flying to depict God's swift and protective care over Jerusalem. This metaphor echoes the protective care in Matthew 23:37; Psalm 91:4; Deuteronomy 32:11; and Ruth 2:12, highlighting God's tender watchfulness.

questions.question: What call to repentance is given in Isaiah 31:6?
options: Turn to the LORD from whom Israel has deeply revolted
Return to Egypt for help and protection
Build new idols of silver and gold
Trust in chariots and horsemen for safety
questions.correctAnswer: Turn to the LORD from whom Israel has deeply revolted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:6 urges Israel to repent from their rebellion and return to God. This call is consistent with themes in Ezekiel 18:30; Joel 2:12-13; Hosea 14:1; and 2 Chronicles 7:14, stressing repentance as the path to restoration.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 31:7, what will Israel do on the day of their repentance?
options: Cast away their idols of silver and gold made by their own hands
Offer more sacrifices to foreign gods
Build new chariots and horses
Seek refuge in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Cast away their idols of silver and gold made by their own hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:7 predicts that Israel will discard their man-made idols as part of genuine repentance. This act aligns with Exodus 32:20; 1 Samuel 15:23; Jeremiah 10:3-5; and 1 John 5:21, reflecting the biblical denunciation of idolatry.

questions.question: What outcome does Isaiah 31:8 describe for the Assyrian invader?
options: He will fall by the sword and be discomfited
He will conquer Jerusalem and establish his rule
He will make a peace treaty with Israel
He will be honored for his strength
questions.correctAnswer: He will fall by the sword and be discomfited
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:8 prophesies the defeat of the Assyrian invader by divine judgment. This theme of God's victory over enemies appears in Psalm 68:1; Nahum 1:9; Zechariah 10:5; and Revelation 19:11-21, affirming God's sovereign defense of His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 31:9 describe the Assyrian’s reaction to the LORD’s fire in Zion?
options: He will flee to his stronghold in fear, and his princes will be afraid
He will gather his armies and attack with confidence
He will surrender peacefully to Jerusalem
He will build altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He will flee to his stronghold in fear, and his princes will be afraid
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:9 reveals the terror the Assyrian will feel because of God's fiery judgment in Zion and Jerusalem. This is consistent with Exodus 15:7; Joel 2:3; Psalm 97:3-6; and Zephaniah 3:8, illustrating the fearful power of God's presence.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly displayed in Isaiah 31:4 where He 'comes down to fight for Mount Zion'?
options: Divine warrior protecting His people
A distant judge who ignores earthly affairs
A passive observer of conflict
A God who relinquishes power to human armies
questions.correctAnswer: Divine warrior protecting His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:4 portrays God as a divine warrior who actively defends His people, a theme consistent with Exodus 15:3; Psalm 24:8; Joshua 5:14-15; and Revelation 19:11, emphasizing God's active role in salvation history.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about human reliance is taught in Isaiah 31:1-3?
options: Trusting in human strength rather than God leads to failure
Human alliances guarantee security
Military power is the ultimate source of salvation
Idols made by hands are more powerful than God
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in human strength rather than God leads to failure
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1-3 teaches that reliance on human military might (horses, chariots, men) rather than God results in downfall. This aligns with Psalm 20:7; Jeremiah 17:5; 1 Corinthians 1:27-29; and Proverbs 21:31, emphasizing God's sovereignty over human strength.

questions.question: The phrase 'whose fire is in Zion, and his furnace in Jerusalem' in Isaiah 31:9 symbolically refers to what aspect of God?
options: His purifying judgment and holy presence
His warm hospitality
His provision of food and shelter
His silence and absence
questions.correctAnswer: His purifying judgment and holy presence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:9 uses fire and furnace imagery to represent God's holy, refining judgment in Zion and Jerusalem. Similar symbolism is found in Malachi 3:2-3; Hebrews 12:29; Revelation 1:14; and Isaiah 6:6-7, highlighting God's holiness and justice.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implicit in God's defense of Jerusalem in Isaiah 31:5?
options: God's ultimate preservation and salvation of His people
The permanent destruction of Jerusalem
The abandonment of Israel to foreign powers
The reliance on earthly kingdoms for peace
questions.correctAnswer: God's ultimate preservation and salvation of His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:5's promise that God will defend and preserve Jerusalem points forward to the eschatological hope of God's final salvation (cf. Revelation 21:2; Zechariah 14:9; Psalm 125:2; Romans 8:28), assuring His people of ultimate victory and security.

questions.question: Which theological theme is underscored by the repeated contrast between human and divine strength in Isaiah 31:1-3?
options: The sovereignty and supremacy of God over human powers
The futility of prayer in times of war
The importance of military alliances
The equality of gods and men
questions.correctAnswer: The sovereignty and supremacy of God over human powers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:1-3 contrasts human military might with the supreme power of God, teaching His sovereignty. This is consistent with Isaiah 40:15-17; Daniel 4:35; Psalm 135:5-6; and Colossians 1:16, affirming God's ultimate authority over all worldly powers.

questions.question: What sin is Israel accused of in Isaiah 31:7 that leads to their need for repentance?
options: Idolatry through silver and gold idols made by their own hands
Oppression of the poor
Abandoning the temple sacrifices
Refusing to keep the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry through silver and gold idols made by their own hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 31:7 identifies idolatry—worship of man-made silver and gold idols—as the sin from which Israel must repent. This sin is condemned throughout Scripture (Exodus 20:4-5; Leviticus 26:1; Jeremiah 2:11; 1 Corinthians 10:14), calling for a return to exclusive worship of God.
